posts.html:
What is headless service?


A headless service is a Kubernetes Service without ClusterIP.

What is the difference?

First, let's see the differences between headless and headful service manifests.

NOTE: Originally, there isn't something like "headful" service in Kubernetes nomenclature. It is used in this article to differentiate services.

After creating both services, it is visible that ClusterIP was not set for headless service.

I have 3 containers (called test-*) that will be included in headless and headful services.

Now, let's check (with usage of dnsutils pod) what addresses will be returned from DNS for particular services.

Can you see the difference? If ClusterIP is set, then only one IP address is returned in answer, thus load balancing is done by the cluster itself. However, if ClusterIP is empty, addresses of all available endpoints are returned, allowing the application to know and decide which target instance to connect to.

Another approach with StatefulSets

With StatefulSets you can achieve the same behavior as with headless service by specifying spec.serviceName field (headful or headless, doesn't matter).

I have created a StatefulSet with 3 pods (test-*).

And pointed a headful service in the spec.

Now, it is possible to resolve specific pods in this service (this is not normally possible).

That's great, you can create an application that can connect to particular instances by name of the pod.

Drawback? Somehow, your client must know how many instances of the target application are there.

Headless service with StatefulSet

If StatefulSet has specified spec.serviceName field and targeted a headless service, then DNS discovery can be used for getting the number of instances available (i.e. 3) and then using the above solution to connect (i.e.: test-0.headful, test-1.headful, test-3.headful).

Where this is useful? One of the best examples is Kafka, where sometimes a particular topic's partition leader is on a different broker than the application connected to. Check the diagram below.
posts.plaintext:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

What is headless service?

A headless service is a Kubernetes Service without ClusterIP.

What is the difference?
First, let's see the differences between headless and headful service manifests.

> NOTE: Originally, there isn't something like "headful" service in Kubernetes
nomenclature. It is used in this article to differentiate services.
After creating both services, it is visible that ClusterIP was not set for 
headless service.

I have 3 containers (called test-*) that will be included in headless and 
headful services.

Now, let's check (with usage of dnsutils pod) what addresses will be returned
from DNS for particular services. 

Can you see the difference? If ClusterIP is set, then only one IP address is
returned in answer, thus load balancing is done by the cluster itself. However,
if ClusterIP is empty, addresses of all available endpoints are returned,
allowing the application to know and decide which target instance to connect to. 



Another approach with StatefulSets
With StatefulSets you can achieve the same behavior as with headless service by
specifying spec.serviceName field (headful or headless, doesn't matter). 

I have created a StatefulSet with 3 pods (test-*). 

And pointed a headful service in the spec.

Now, it is possible to resolve specific pods in this service (this is not
normally possible). 

That's great, you can create an application that can connect to particular
instances by name of the pod.

Drawback? Somehow, your client must know how many instances of the target
application are there.

Headless service with StatefulSet
If StatefulSet has specified spec.serviceName field and targeted a headless 
service, then DNS discovery can be used for getting the number of instances
available (i.e. 3) and then using the above solution to connect (i.e.: 
test-0.headful, test-1.headful, test-3.headful).

Where this is useful? One of the best examples is Kafka, where sometimes a
particular topic's partition leader is on a different broker than the
application connected to. Check the diagram below.

posts.html:
What is kube-score?

Project repository is explaining the purpose of this tool in following way:

kube-score is a tool that performs static code analysis of your Kubernetes object definitions. The output is a list of recommendations of what you can improve to make your application more secure and resilient.

How to run it?

Example

Test your manifests online

Difference with kube-bench?

posts.html:
Articles

  1. Docker Alternatives
    Link: https://blog.logrocket.com/top-docker-alternatives-2022/
    One tool I would add to the list is nerdctl, it is nearly 1:1 mapping of Docker CLI experience.
  2. A Closer Look at NSA/CISA Kubernetes Hardening Guidance
    Link: https://kubernetes.io/blog/2021/10/05/nsa-cisa-kubernetes-hardening-guidance/
  3. Build and deploy microservices with Kubernetes and Dapr
    Link: https://developers.redhat.com/articles/2021/08/12/build-and-deploy-microservices-kubernetes-and-dapr#how_to_install_dapr
  4. Create and Manage Kubernetes Clusters with Cluster API and ArgoCD
    Link: https://piotrminkowski.com/2021/12/03/create-kubernetes-clusters-with-cluster-api-and-argocd/
  5. OpenFaaS - Run Containerized Functions On Your Own Terms
    Link: https://iximiuz.com/en/posts/openfaas-case-study/

Videos

  1. Dapr, Lego for Microservices
posts.plaintext:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Articles
 1. Docker Alternatives
    Link: https://blog.logrocket.com/top-docker-alternatives-2022/
    One tool I would add to the list is nerdctl, it is nearly 1:1 mapping of
    Docker CLI experience.
 2. A Closer Look at NSA/CISA Kubernetes Hardening Guidance
    Link: 
    https://kubernetes.io/blog/2021/10/05/nsa-cisa-kubernetes-hardening-guidance/
 3. Build and deploy microservices with Kubernetes and Dapr
    Link: 
    https://developers.redhat.com/articles/2021/08/12/build-and-deploy-microservices-kubernetes-and-dapr#how_to_install_dapr
 4. Create and Manage Kubernetes Clusters with Cluster API and ArgoCD
    Link: 
    https://piotrminkowski.com/2021/12/03/create-kubernetes-clusters-with-cluster-api-and-argocd/
 5. OpenFaaS - Run Containerized Functions On Your Own Terms
    Link: https://iximiuz.com/en/posts/openfaas-case-study/

posts.html:
Articles

  1. K3S + K3D = K8S: a new perfect match for dev and test
    Link: https://www.sokube.ch/post/k3s-k3d-k8s-a-new-perfect-match-for-dev-and-test
  2. Using Kubernetes's new Bound Service Account Tokens for secure workload identity
    Link: https://linkerd.io/2021/12/28/using-kubernetess-new-bound-service-account-tokens-for-secure-workload-identity/
  3. Kubernetes: Building a CI/CD pipeline using ArgoCD, Tekton and Kaniko
    Link:
    https://www.ameyalokare.com/technology/kubernetes/ci/cd/gitops/argocd/tekton/2021/12/27/kubernetes-argocd-tekton.html
  4. Top 20 Dockerfile best practices
    Link: https://sysdig.com/blog/dockerfile-best-practices/
  5. Docker vs dind images
    Link: https://www.caktusgroup.com/blog/2020/02/25/docker-image/
  6. Serverless Open-Source Frameworks: OpenFaaS, Knative, & more
    Link: https://www.cncf.io/blog/2020/04/13/serverless-open-source-frameworks-openfaas-knative-more/
  7. Kourier: A lightweight Knative Serving ingress
    Link: https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2020/06/30/kourier-a-lightweight-knative-serving-ingress#what_is_knative_
  8. Prometheus Operator ServiceMonitor Troubleshooting
    Link: https://managedkube.com/prometheus/operator/servicemonitor/troubleshooting/2019/11/07/prometheus-operator-servicemonitor-troubleshooting.html
  9. Kubernetes-in-Kubernetes and the WEDOS PXE bootable server farm
    Link: https://kubernetes.io/blog/2021/12/22/kubernetes-in-kubernetes-and-pxe-bootable-server-farm/
  10. Using Admission Controllers to Detect Container Drift at Runtime
    Link: https://kubernetes.io/blog/2021/12/21/admission-controllers-for-container-drift/

Projects

  1. Kubernetes in Kubernetes
    Link: https://github.com/kvaps/kubernetes-in-kubernetes
  2. Kubefarm
    Link: https://github.com/kvaps/kubefarm
  3. Gardener
    Link: https://github.com/gardener/gardener
  4. Shipper
    Link: https://github.com/bookingcom/shipper
  5. Kubebuilder
    Link: https://kubebuilder.io/cronjob-tutorial/new-api.html
posts.plaintext:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Articles
 1.  K3S + K3D = K8S: a new perfect match for dev and test
     Link: 
     https://www.sokube.ch/post/k3s-k3d-k8s-a-new-perfect-match-for-dev-and-test
 2.  Using Kubernetes's new Bound Service Account Tokens for secure workload
     identity
     Link: 
     https://linkerd.io/2021/12/28/using-kubernetess-new-bound-service-account-tokens-for-secure-workload-identity/
 3.  Kubernetes: Building a CI/CD pipeline using ArgoCD, Tekton and Kaniko
     Link:
     https://www.ameyalokare.com/technology/kubernetes/ci/cd/gitops/argocd/tekton/2021/12/27/kubernetes-argocd-tekton.html
 4.  Top 20 Dockerfile best practices
     Link: https://sysdig.com/blog/dockerfile-best-practices/
 5.  Docker vs dind images
     Link: https://www.caktusgroup.com/blog/2020/02/25/docker-image/
 6.  Serverless Open-Source Frameworks: OpenFaaS, Knative, & more
     Link: 
     https://www.cncf.io/blog/2020/04/13/serverless-open-source-frameworks-openfaas-knative-more/
 7.  Kourier: A lightweight Knative Serving ingress
     Link: 
     https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2020/06/30/kourier-a-lightweight-knative-serving-ingress#what_is_knative_
 8.  Prometheus Operator ServiceMonitor Troubleshooting
     Link: 
     https://managedkube.com/prometheus/operator/servicemonitor/troubleshooting/2019/11/07/prometheus-operator-servicemonitor-troubleshooting.html
 9.  Kubernetes-in-Kubernetes and the WEDOS PXE bootable server farm
     Link: 
     https://kubernetes.io/blog/2021/12/22/kubernetes-in-kubernetes-and-pxe-bootable-server-farm/
 10. Using Admission Controllers to Detect Container Drift at Runtime
     Link: 
     https://kubernetes.io/blog/2021/12/21/admission-controllers-for-container-drift/

Projects
 1. Kubernetes in Kubernetes
    Link: https://github.com/kvaps/kubernetes-in-kubernetes
 2. Kubefarm
    Link: https://github.com/kvaps/kubefarm
 3. Gardener
    Link: https://github.com/gardener/gardener
 4. Shipper
    Link: https://github.com/bookingcom/shipper
 5. Kubebuilder
    Link: https://kubebuilder.io/cronjob-tutorial/new-api.html

posts.title: Tool Stack
posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[],"markups":[["a",["href","https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/krew"]],["a",["href","https://krew.sigs.k8s.io/plugins/"]],["a",["href","https://github.com/derailed/k9s"]],["a",["href","https://github.com/wagoodman/dive"]],["em"],["a",["href","https://www.notion.so/"]],["a",["href","https://github.com/casdoor/casdoor"]]],"sections":[[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"CLI"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[0],1,"krew"],[0,[],0," ("],[0,[1],1,"available plugins"],[0,[],0,", I personally use: ns, ctx, example, explore)"]]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Kubernetes Related"]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Cluster Management"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[2],1,"k9s"],[0,[],0," - CLI GUI tool to manage single/many Kubernetes clusters with access to all resources, even CRD's"]]]],[1,"h3",[[0,[],0,"Image Analysis"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[3],1,"dive"],[0,[],0," - "],[0,[4],1,"A tool for exploring a docker image, layer contents, and discovering ways to shrink the size of your Docker/OCI image."]]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Notes and ToDo's"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[5],1,"Notion"],[0,[],0," - public ToDo/Notes app with ability to create timelines, boards, lists and more"]]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"OIDC"]]],[3,"ul",[[[0,[],0,"Keycloak"]],[[0,[6],1,"Casdoor"],[0,[],0," "]]]]],"ghostVersion":"4.0"}
posts.html:
CLI

  • krew (available plugins, I personally use: ns, ctx, example, explore)

Kubernetes Related

Cluster Management

  • k9s - CLI GUI tool to manage single/many Kubernetes clusters with access to all resources, even CRD's

Image Analysis

  • dive - A tool for exploring a docker image, layer contents, and discovering ways to shrink the size of your Docker/OCI image.

Notes and ToDo's

  • Notion - public ToDo/Notes app with ability to create timelines, boards, lists and more

OIDC

  • Keycloak
  • Casdoor
posts.plaintext:
CLI
 * krew [https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/krew] (available plugins
   [https://krew.sigs.k8s.io/plugins/], I personally use: ns, ctx, example,
   explore)

Kubernetes Related
Cluster Management
 * k9s [https://github.com/derailed/k9s] - CLI GUI tool to manage single/many
   Kubernetes clusters with access to all resources, even CRD's

Image Analysis
 * dive [https://github.com/wagoodman/dive] - A tool for exploring a docker
   image, layer contents, and discovering ways to shrink the size of your
   Docker/OCI image.

Notes and ToDo's
 * Notion [https://www.notion.so/] - public ToDo/Notes app with ability to
   create timelines, boards, lists and more

OIDC
 * Keycloak
 * Casdoor [https://github.com/casdoor/casdoor]
